docs.lead_paragraph: The National Association for the Advancement of Colored People is locked in a standoff with the Internal Revenue Service, preferring to risk its tax exemption rather than hand over documents for an I.R.S. review that the civil rights group contends is politically motivated. While it is rare for an organization to defy the I.R.S. openly, the N.A.A.C.P. is not the only group that believes it is being made a government target for its positions on issues.

headline.main: Nonprofit Groups Question Motive for Federal Actions

docs.abstract: About dozen nonprofit organizations publicly contend that government agencies and Congressional offices have used reviews, audits, investigations and threat of loss of federal money to discourage them from activities and advocacy that in any way challenge government policies; say more groups are complaining quietly; government agencies, which are under increasing financial pressure themselves, say they are merely enforcing rules on use of public money and nonprofit assets; federal law prohibits organizations from using government financing for lobbying purposes, and tax law limits use of charitable assets in general for lobbying; National Assn for Advancement of Colored People, for example, is locked in standoff with IRS, preferring to risk its tax exemption rather than hand over documents for IRS review that civil rights group contends is politically motivated; other examples cited; photos (L)
docs.snippet: The N.A.A.C.P., which is locked in a standoff with the I.R.S., is not the only group that believes it is being made a government target for its positions on issues.

keywords.name: organizations
keywords.value: NATIONAL ASSN FOR THE ADVANCEMENT OF COLORED PEOPLE

docs.lead_paragraph: 1. Symptoms The middle-aged man sobbed quietly as the doctor entered the darkened hospital room. A tall woman in a baggy blue sweater tenderly placed a cool, wet cloth on the patient's forehead. His salt-and-pepper hair lay plastered to his scalp, and his round face was flushed and shiny with the combination of sweat and tears. ''Doc, I'm so afraid,'' he said, his raspy voice nearly a whisper. ''Can't you tell me what's wrong?'' The woman squeezed her husband's hand in silent reassurance, but her face was lined with worry. Dr. Kevin Sterling, the young resident charged with the patient's care, sat down next to the bed.

headline.main: Nocturnal fever; Swollen lymph nodes; Joint pain
headline.kicker: THE WAY WE LIVE NOW: 3-20-05: DIAGNOSIS

docs.abstract: Lisa Sanders article on diagnosis of Adult Still's disease in 51-year-old man complaining of nocturnal fever, swollen lymph nodes and joint pain; photos (L)
docs.snippet: Figuring out the cause of a patient's woes sometimes takes round-the-clock observation.

docs.lead_paragraph: THERE were two ailing boys, both appropriately named Innocent, at a makeshift hospital here. They didn't know it but they represented the two different ways of dying in Africa's wars. The older of the two Innocents, at 14, was a victim of the most obvious killer -- violence. He had machete wounds to his neck, suffered as he tried to escape the tribal militiamen who swooped down on his village recently. Innocent's mother was killed. The men with machetes tried to sever Innocent's head, as well, but for some reason never finished the job. Innocent's neck had a series of deep hack marks when he arrived at the hospital in the arms of his father.

headline.main: The World; Beyond the Bullets and Blades

docs.abstract: Marc Lacey article holds that vast majority of those who die in African war zones are not done in directly by warriors; notes that studies in Sudan by Physicians for Human Rights and in Congo by International Rescue Committee conclude that many Africans die because of conditions created by wars in extremely fragile societies; says IRC survey found that most deaths were due to maladies that are easily preventable and treatable in other parts of world; graphs; photos (M)
docs.snippet: The vast majority of those who die in African war zones are not done in directly by warriors.

docs.lead_paragraph: Siemens, the world's second-largest maker of medical equipment, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy CTI Molecular Imaging for about $967 million. CTI shareholders will receive $20.50 a share in cash, or 17 percent more than CTI's closing stock price on Thursday. Siemens, based in Munich, and CTI, based in Knoxville, Tenn., have been allied since 1987 through a joint venture for equipment that helps doctors detect diseases like cancer or cardiac diseases. The companies last year also created a marketing agreement for their imaging devices. ''We worked closely in a joint venture with CTI over the last 17 years now,'' said Michael Reitermann, president of the nuclear medicine division in Siemens Medical. ''The importance of medical imaging led us to take this step now.''

headline.main: SIEMENS TO BUY CTI MOLECULAR FOR $967 MILLION

docs.abstract: Siemens agrees to purchase CTI Molecular Imaging for about $967 million (S)
docs.snippet: Siemens, the world's second-largest maker of medical equipment, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy CTI Molecular Imaging for about $967 million. CTI shareholders will receive $20.50 a share in cash, or 17 percent more than CTI's closing stock...

docs.lead_paragraph: For the first time in two centuries, the current generation of children in America may have shorter life expectancies than their parents, according to a new report, which contends that the rapid rise in childhood obesity, if left unchecked, could shorten life spans by as much as five years. The report, to be published Thursday in The New England Journal of Medicine, says the prevalence and severity of obesity is so great, especially in children, that the associated diseases and complications -- Type 2 diabetes, heart disease, kidney failure, cancer -- are likely to strike people at younger and younger ages.

headline.main: Children's Life Expectancy Being Cut Short by Obesity

docs.abstract: Study published in New England Journal of Medicine says rapid rise in childhood obesity, if left unchecked, could shorten life spans by as much as five years; cites associated diseases and complications from obesity; says average life expectancy of today's adult, roughly 77 years, is at least four to nine months shorter than it would be if there were no obesity; Dr David S Ludwig, director of obesity program at Children's Hospital Boston says children today could be first generation to live shorter, less healthful lives than their parents (M)
docs.snippet: A new report contends that the rapid rise in childhood obesity, if left unchecked, could shorten life spans by as much as five years.

docs.lead_paragraph: Value of Antioxidants Q. What happens in our bodies that creates a need for antioxidants? A. Oxidation is a chemical reaction involving the element oxygen. To simplify, exposure to charged particles of oxygen theoretically leads to the deterioration of human cells and DNA somewhat in the way that an apple slice turns brown. But as cooks know, brushing the apple slice with lemon juice, which contains acidic antioxidants, will retard the process. Highly reactive charged particles of oxygen called free radicals form naturally as extra electrons attach themselves to about 5 percent of inhaled oxygen. In research that became widely known two decades ago, oxidation caused by free radicals was implicated in many diseases, including cancer and heart disease, and in the aging process itself.
docs.abstract: Q & A column describes why humans need antioxidants; discusses their potential health benefits; drawing (S)
docs.snippet: Value of Antioxidants    Q. What happens in our bodies that creates a need for antioxidants?    A. Oxidation is a chemical reaction involving the element oxygen. To simplify, exposure to charged particles of oxygen theoretically leads to the...

docs.lead_paragraph: THE CLAIM -- A cold is contagious only before symptoms emerge. THE FACTS -- The signs are unmistakable. A fit of sneezing, a sore throat, stuffy congestion so miserable that seemingly no amount of tissue can help. Anyone can spot the onset of a winter cold, but many experts say that few people know when a person who has picked up the virus actually becomes contagious, and for how long.
docs.abstract: Individuals with cold become contagious around day before symptoms appear and can continue to spread cold for several days after signs of illness disappear; drawing (S)
docs.snippet: Many experts say that few people know when a person who has picked up a winter cold actually becomes contagious, and for how long.

docs.lead_paragraph: While early reports of the deadliness of human avian influenza suggested that about 90 percent of the victims died, there are growing signs that the disease's true death rate is much lower -- although still high enough to kill many millions of people if the worst fears about its spread come to fruition. Few acute infectious diseases have death rates exceeding 5 or 10 percent. Exceptions are rabies, which is nearly always fatal, and Ebola and Lassa fever, with reported death rates ranging from 25 to 90 percent. The death rate for garden-variety flu for children, the elderly or the immuno-compromised is less than 1 percent in developed countries. At least 20 million people worldwide died in the 1918 influenza pandemic, with an estimated death rate of 2 percent.

headline.main: True Toll of Avian Flu Remains a Mystery

docs.abstract: Avian influenza, which has received attention of worldwide medical community as possible next pandemic, may have lower death rate for humans who become infected than originally believed; roadblocks to accurate assessment of illness include poor medical testing facilities, lack of governmental support and possibility that many milder cases are going completely undetected; World Health Organization sets current death rate from avian influenza in Southeast Asia at 67 percent; photo (M)
docs.snippet: There are signs that the disease's death rate is much lower than previously suggested  although still high enough to kill many millions of people.
